metric_description: Sensitivity is the ability of a test to correctly classify a case as positive (e.g., having some condition or disease). It is also sometimes referred to as the true positive rate or recall.
references: Parikh R, Mathai A, Parikh S, Chandra Sekhar G, Thomas R. Understanding and using sensitivity, specificity and predictive values. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2008;56(1):45–50.

metric_description: Specificity is the ability of test to correctly classify a case as negative (e.g., not having some condition or disease). It is also sometimes referred to as the true negative rate.
references: Parikh R, Mathai A, Parikh S, Chandra Sekhar G, Thomas R. Understanding and using sensitivity, specificity and predictive values. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2008;56(1):45–50.

metric_description: Positive predictive value is the percentage of cases with positive test results that actually have the condition being tested for (e.g., the disease or symptoms).
references: Parikh R, Mathai A, Parikh S, Chandra Sekhar G, Thomas R. Understanding and using sensitivity, specificity and predictive values. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2008;56(1):45–50.

metric_description: Negative predictive value is percentage of cases with a negative test results that do not actually have the condition being tested for (e.g., the disease or symptoms).
references: Parikh R, Mathai A, Parikh S, Chandra Sekhar G, Thomas R. Understanding and using sensitivity, specificity and predictive values. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2008;56(1):45–50.

metric_description: The F1 score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall, meaning that it penalizes extreme values of either.
references: Hicks SA, Strümke I, Thambawita V, Hammou M, Riegler MA, Halvorsen P, et al. On evaluation metrics for medical applications of artificial intelligence. Sci Rep. 2022 Apr 8;12:5979.

metric_description: Accuracy is the ratio of the correctly classified samples to the total number of samples in the evaluation dataset
references: Hicks SA, Strümke I, Thambawita V, Hammou M, Riegler MA, Halvorsen P, et al. On evaluation metrics for medical applications of artificial intelligence. Sci Rep. 2022 Apr 8;12:5979.

metric_description: The area under the ROC curve (ROC AUC) is a measure how well a test is table to discriminate whether a specific condition is present or not present. An AUC of 0.5 represents a test that performs no better than random chance, while an AUC of 1.0 represents a test with perfect performance. The ROC AUC is calculated by plotting the plotting sensitivity (true positive rate) on the y-axis against 1–specificity (false positive rate) on the x-axis for the various values, and then calculating the area under the curve generated based on those values.
references: Hoo ZH, Candlish J, Teare D. What is an ROC curve? Emerg Med J. 2017 Jun;34(6):357–9.

metric_description: Precision is calculated as the proportion of positive test results that were actually positive (e.g., having some disease or symptoms)
references: Hicks SA, Strümke I, Thambawita V, Hammou M, Riegler MA, Halvorsen P, et al. On evaluation metrics for medical applications of artificial intelligence. Sci Rep. 2022 Apr 8;12:5979.

metric_description: Pearson’s correlation coefficient is a measurement quantifying the strength of linear association between two variables. It takes values of −1 through +1, where values of −1 or +1 indicate a perfect linear relationship between two variables, and a value of 0 indicates no linear relationship.
references: Britannica. Pearson’s correlation coefficient [Internet]. 2023 [cited 2023 Sep 22]. Available from: https://www.britannica.com/topic/Pearsons-correlation-coefficient
